packages.title: Discrete event stimulation toolset to perform cost effectiveness analysis for health economics
packages.description:
WARDEN is a user-friendly package that facilitates the use of discrete event simulations with or without resource constraints for cost-effectiveness analysis. The package supports a flexible, transparent, practical approach to discrete event simulation while keeping an acceptable performance.

The current version supports:

Discrete event simulation models, Markov/semi-Markov models and hybrid models using parallel and non-parallel engines
Constrained and unconstrained models (with or without interactivity between patients)
Seamlessly integrating data.frames and other objects into the model
Delayed execution of the main inputs to facilitate readability of the model
Implementation of structural and parameter uncertainty
Helper functions to facilitate drawing of time to events and the use of hazard ratios, as well as other functions to facilitate transparency
Performing cost-effectiveness and uncertainty analysis
packages.use_cases: Perform resource constrained and unconstrained discrete event stimulation cost effectiveness models
packages.unique_features: User friendly, many helper functions, easy to implement and debug

packages.title: Fitting distributions with parameter uncertainty using the objective Bayesian method of calibrating priors
packages.description:
This package is to help climate scientists, actuaries and other risk modellers fit distributions and regression models, but including parameter uncertainty. Including parameter uncertainty gives predictive distributions that give well calibrated probabilities and return levels of future data points.
This compares with standard methods for fitting distributions, such as maxlik, which ignore parameter uncertainty, and underestimate the probabilities of future extremes. 
The methods in this package either eliminate this underestimation, or greatly reduce it (depending on the model).

The package provides the usual methods (d for density, p for probability, q for quantiles and r for random deviates).
It’s fast and straightforward to use.
It’s the only package that provides such easy-to-use functionality for fitting predictive distributions, and the only package that provides routines for testing the calibration of fitted distributions.

There are 3 related journal papers, in climate, actuarial and statistical journals:

https://doi.org/10.5194/ascmo-11-1-2025
https://doi.org/10.1017/S1748499525100237
https://doi.org/10.3390/stats8040109
packages.use_cases:
In climate science: modelling the probability distribution of annual maximum temperatures in London based on data from the last 70 years, with the goal of understanding the probabilities of what might happen next year

In actuarial science: modelling the probability distribution of losses to an insurance portfolio based on losses from the last 20 years, with the goal of understanding the probabilities of what might happen next year
packages.similar_packages:
Similar to fitdistrplus, but includes parameter uncertainty, and so produces predictive distributions, not just best fit distributions.

Similar to the various other extreme value packages in R (such as extRemes, evd, evir, climextRemes, extremeStat, fExtremes) but makes it possible (or at least easier) to include objective parameter uncertainty, which is necessary for well calibrated probabilities. 

Similar to the various Bayesian packages in R (such as extRemes, MCMC4Extremes, revdbayes, texmex) but faster because it uses asymptotic expansions, and easier because you don't have to specify a prior, or burn-in or convergence criteria.  

A slightly simplified version of fitdistcp is also available in Python.
packages.unique_features:
This is the only package that provides straightforward commands for fitting distributions with parameter uncertainty, i.e. predictive distributions.
Including parameter uncertainty is essential when distributions are being for risk assessment.
